text: In Australia SARS was declared a quarantinable disease under the Quarantine Act 1908 and policy guidelines for health professionals, airline and border control staff and the general public were developed by the Department of Health and Ageing, which also led an inter-departmental task force to monitor world developments. Until July 2003, when the WHO announced that no country was still considered SARS-affected, international aircraft arriving at Australian airports were required to obtain

clearance, nurses were posted at airports and restrictions on elective surgery were placed on travellers returning from affected countries [7] . During the period of WHO's alert, Australia had reported only five probable, and one laboratory-confirmed, case of SARS.
